metadata.title: How To Pass Tier 1 & 2 Selections Part 3/3: Tier 1 Selections
metadata.description:
Welcome to Part 3 of my series on How to Pass Tier 1 and Tier 2 Selections. In this video, we’re diving deep into Tier 1 selection — what truly separates it from Tier 2 and how you can prepare for it.

Tier 2 selections (like Ranger, SEAL, Special Forces) are already tough, but Tier 1 is another level entirely. It’s not just about surviving physically. It’s about being able to lead and operate alone in the most high-risk environments with zero guidance or backup.

Key differences:

Nearly all events are individual. There is no team to help you push through.

No yelling or “motivation” from cadre. You won’t even know the evaluation criteria.

You get instructions once, maybe twice. No excuses.

Psychological evaluation is constant. They want thinkers and problem-solvers who stay calm under extreme stress.

In Tier 2, you might find strength in defying someone telling you to quit or lean on your team to keep going. That doesn’t exist in Tier 1. It’s all on you.

Top 3 tips to prepare:
✅ Rucking: Learn to run-ruck. You’ll never make time standards if you just walk.
✅ Land Navigation: Especially for Delta Force selection in West Virginia. It’s brutally hard terrain where you can’t just dead-reckon.
✅ Mental Preparation: Make decisions under stress. Face no-win scenarios, pick a path, and commit.

Tier 1 selection is designed to see if you can plan and lead a solo mission in a foreign environment with no margin for error.

If you’re aiming for the pinnacle of special operations, this is the level of preparation you need.

Like, comment, and subscribe for more on selection prep, mindset training, and lessons from Special Operations.

#Tier1Selection #DeltaForce #cag #SEALTeam6 #devgru #intelligencesupportactivity #TFO #SpecialOperations #Military #army #selection #Mindset #Leadership #GreenBeret #training #preparation #StoicViking

transcript.full_text:
So this is my three-part series on how to pass Tier one and Tier two selections. Part three will cover Tier one selections. So quick recap of my background, I'm former Special Forces and a Tier one operator, and I was able to be a cadre for a Tier one selection later on in my Tier one career.

So Tier one units, we're basically going to cover the main three operational Tier one units, which is SEAL Team Six, Delta Force, and the Intelligence Support activity. Also blue, green, or orange, you know, based on the task force colors I've talked about in the different, the other two different videos. So what separates these three different units is one is that all three of them are modeled after the British SAS. And then when they were created, they decided to go with a different psychology and the way different way about how they do selections. So quick caveat, of the three Tier one units, I'm intimately familiar with both Delta Force and Intelligence Support activity. Actually both of them are, Intelligence Support Activity which was created later, directly modeled theirs off of Delta's selection. SEAL Team Six has a lot of similarities, but they have a few differences of the three. And I reached out to a couple SEAL Team Six buddies who I've served with and asked them for a couple clarifications about some of the stuff that I would be talking about in this video, just to make sure that it is correct and accurate.

So the biggest difference between Tier two and Tier one selections is first, Tier one selections, almost all the events are individual events. There's very little to no team events. The second part is there's no negative or positive reinforcements. They're not yelling at you. They're not screaming at you. They're not telling you to quit. They don't tell you anything other than instructions that are extremely stoic, and you don't know the evaluation criteria. You are basically given instructions once, maybe twice depending on the situation, and that's it. And then you're expected to complete those tasks without any little to no knowledge about the evaluation criteria. For example, if you go on a ruck, you don't know what your time needs to be. The only way that you know that you didn't meet the evaluation criteria is you'll randomly be whisked away on a truck, and, uh, they'll, you'll be told that you're out and you won't see anybody you ever saw on the selection ever again.

There's a couple reasons why they have a different psychology compared to the Tier two selection. Most people who are in Tier one selections are coming from Tier two units. Well, especially SEAL Team Six, you have to be a SEAL, you know, even to go to SEAL Team Six. So they know that you've been through the suck. They know that you know how to go through hard shit, and they don't need to test that. That's not what they're looking for. They're looking to see how much skill and ability that you have, and also what is your mental capacity to deal with problems on your own with little to no instruction. And they even put you through no-win scenarios just to see how you deal with them. Because one of the advantages when you're going to that Tier two selection and you're getting yelled at and you're being told to quit and you've got your other fellow candidates next to you, you can actually bond and you can actually find strength from each other. You can't do that because almost all the events are individual. You have to rely completely on yourself. And because you don't know the evaluation criteria, you just have to do the best that you can as fast as you can. Cuz 90% of the events are going to be individual. You're by yourself and you can only rely on yourself. You're not just being evaluated on your physical and tactical abilities, you are being studied psychologically through your mental toughness and your mental agility. They want thinkers and problem solvers. Operators who can adapt and lead and perform in any environment without guidance. The Tier two tests if you can survive. Tier one tests you if you can either lead a mission or run one solo in either a foreign country or a foreign territory with no backup, no oversight, and no margin for error. And at face value, a lot of people will think that like, oh, you know, I'm not getting yelled at, it's not as bad. Actually, it screws with people a lot more because people feed off that yelling when people are telling you to quit, you know, they're like, you know what, I'm just going to do it to say, fuck you. But when you have nobody telling you that you're not doing it right or you're not doing it wrong, and also, you don't know what time you have to beat, that screws with people. And I've seen some pretty successful Tier two operators falter to this. And it really weeds out the operators who are not mentally independently tough.

So I'm going to give you three tips on how to pass Tier one selections. The first is rucking. And while I did cover rucking in Tier two, I'm telling you, it is so important that you have to be able to ruck run no matter what you're doing. You have to be able to move fast because the time evaluation for any ruck movement in the Tier one selections is extremely high. You have to go fast. If you cannot ruck run, you cannot pass these selections. And if you're currently training for this, learning how to ruck run and how to train up to this is can be very problematic if you try to do it too quickly. I would recommend at least a six to nine month to a year long pre-train up for a Tier one selection just because of how stressful it can be on your body. If you tried to train up too quickly, you will hurt yourself. So the second part is you actually need to be good at land nav. You cannot dead reckon on these Tier one courses, especially Delta's. Delta Force's selection is in probably the worst terrain I've ever seen in my life. You cannot dead reckon anything. You have to be able to terrain associate and you have to be able to move fast while doing it. Quick recommendation for anybody, if you're planning to go to Delta Force selection, I would go find a civilian tracker in the somewhere in the areas of West Virginia and do a one week land nav course. Trust me, it will help you. Not only is it the worst terrain I've ever seen and the hardest land nav, you're going to be moving like 20 miles a day, if not more, and that's all with a ruck on, and there's a fast ass time stamp. And the third part is mentally prepare yourself. And while the first two parts really kind of cover physical preparation, because if you don't properly prepare yourself, I'm telling you, just having heart will not get you through a Tier one selection. You have to physically prepare yourself. Almost everybody who drops out of a Tier one selection, all of them passed Tier two. They have heart, but their bodies broke down because the physical stress that you will go through in a Tier selection is beyond anything you've ever seen. And if anybody knows, there's a reason why they Delta Force is called The Long Walk. The third part is mental preparedness and I cannot stress this part enough. You have to develop a level of mental independence and resilience and your attention to detail needs to be completely spot on. Anytime that they give you instructions, you have to pay attention. You have to memorize it. You're going to be given situations, you have to think in the situation, you have to make a decision, and then you have to go with it. They're going to study you on how you perform in these situations. They are going to create scenarios where you're put in a lot of stress and you're going to be giving really hard decisions, you just have to make a decision and go with it. And this especially comes down to during selection, you will be presented with some no-win situations. All right? The worst thing that you can do is be indecisive. Make a decision and then follow it through no matter what. Trust me. So if you show up to a Tier one selection, physically prepared, you can ruck run for days, you know how to land nav no matter where it is, and you are mentally prepared to tackle any situation that anybody sends at you, even if it's a no-win situation, you will be able to pass. You will be able to make it. And trust me when I tell you this, it'll be one of the hardest but probably the greatest experiences of your life. There's a reason why Tier one operators are even looked at in the civilian world as the equivalent to professional and Olympic athletes because of what they've had to accomplish to get to that level. And me going to selection is still to this day one of the greatest experiences of my life. I hope this was helpful. This concludes my three-part series of how to pass Tier one and Tier two selections. If you have any questions or comments, feel free to comment on the video or send me a DM. Once again, I appreciate you guys and sorry I took so long for me to do part three.

key_points.text: The three main operational Tier one units covered are SEAL Team Six, Delta Force, and the Intelligence Support Activity.
Tier one selections are primarily individual events with no team components, unlike Tier two selections.
There is no positive or negative reinforcement in Tier one selections; instructors are stoic, and evaluation criteria are unknown to candidates.
Tier one selection tests an operator's ability to solve problems independently and lead missions solo without guidance or backup.
All three major Tier one units were modeled after the British SAS but developed different selection psychologies.
The Intelligence Support Activity's selection was directly modeled on Delta Force's selection process.
To pass Tier one selection, candidates must master three key areas: ruck running, advanced land navigation, and mental preparedness.
Ruck running proficiency is non-negotiable for Tier one selection due to extremely high time standards.
Advanced land navigation, specifically terrain association, is critical, as dead reckoning is insufficient for the difficult courses, especially Delta's.
Mental preparedness involves developing mental independence, resilience, attention to detail, and decisiveness, especially in no-win scenarios.
The speaker is a former Special Forces and Tier one operator who also served as a cadre for a Tier one selection.
The speaker consulted with SEAL Team Six members to ensure the accuracy of the information presented.
Most candidates for Tier one selection come from Tier two units, so their basic toughness is already assumed.
Candidates for SEAL Team Six must already be a Navy SEAL.
The psychological stress of not knowing the standards and having no external feedback can cause even successful Tier two operators to fail.
A pre-training period of six months to a year is recommended for Tier one selection to avoid injury from the intense physical demands.
The terrain for Delta Force's selection, likely in West Virginia, is described as the worst the speaker has ever seen.
A one-week civilian land navigation course in West Virginia is recommended for those preparing for Delta Force selection.
Candidates in Delta's selection can expect to move 20 or more miles per day with a ruck and aggressive time limits.
Most dropouts from Tier one selection are due to physical breakdown, not a lack of heart.
Delta Force's selection is nicknamed 'The Long Walk' due to its grueling nature.
In no-win scenarios, being decisive and following through with a decision is more important than the decision itself.
Tier one operators are considered equivalent to professional and Olympic athletes in the civilian world due to the high level of achievement required.
This video is the third and final part of a series on passing Tier one and Tier two selections.
Tier one units are sometimes referred to by task force colors: blue, green, or orange.
Tier one selections are designed to identify thinkers and problem-solvers, not just physically tough individuals.
Candidates are studied psychologically for their mental toughness and agility.
Failure is communicated impersonally; candidates who don't meet the standard are simply removed from the course.
The individual nature of events forces candidates to rely completely on themselves, removing the ability to draw strength from peers.
Indecisiveness is the worst possible trait a candidate can display during selection.

summary:
This analysis is based on a transcript from the third part of a three-part video series by a former Special Forces and Tier one operator, who also served as selection cadre. The video details the nature of Tier one selections, focusing on the three primary US units: SEAL Team Six, Delta Force, and the Intelligence Support Activity (ISA). The speaker, leveraging his intimate knowledge of Delta and ISA selections and insights from SEAL Team Six colleagues, contrasts Tier one and Tier two selection processes. A core distinction is that Tier one units, all modeled originally on the British SAS, have evolved distinct psychological approaches to their selections, which are almost entirely individual-based events.

The psychological dimension of Tier one selection is its most defining and challenging feature. Unlike the overt pressure of Tier two selections, Tier one assessments are characterized by a lack of feedback, both positive and negative. Candidates receive stoic, minimal instructions and are unaware of the evaluation criteria. This environment is designed to test an individual's intrinsic motivation, problem-solving skills under ambiguity, and mental independence, as they cannot draw strength from teamwork or react against instructors. The process is designed to find thinkers and leaders who can operate autonomously in high-stakes environments with no support, effectively testing not just if they can survive, but if they can lead or run a mission solo.

To pass these demanding selections, the speaker provides three critical tips. First is mastering ruck running, as the time standards are exceptionally high and it is a foundational requirement. Second is advanced land navigation, emphasizing terrain association over dead reckoning, particularly for Delta Force's notoriously difficult course in West Virginia, for which a specialized civilian course is recommended. The third and most stressed tip is mental preparedness, which encompasses developing profound mental resilience, independence, and flawless attention to detail. Candidates must be decisive, especially in manufactured no-win scenarios, as the process ruthlessly weeds out those who are not physically prepared for the immense stress—nicknamed 'The Long Walk' for Delta—or mentally capable of absolute self-reliance.
